metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
COPY
Wednesday, Oct 11 th. 1944.
Lt.Comdr.J.M.Legendre,USNR.
Box 166, Commandant,
Navy [number] 128, FPO San Francisco.
Dear Morris-
Where are you and Sid now ? I wrote you an air-mail
letter form around here on Sept 24. I haven't received a reply , so
imagine that it arrived after you had left for the mainland on your 
expected "leave".If so , and if this reaches you while you are in
Washington , I think that perhaps you can be of some help to me,
and thats the reason for this letter. I'm sending it to your usual
address at Navy [number]128 with a request on the envelope that it please 
be "forwarded’ , so trust it reaches you.
I have just received an answer to my request for inactive duty.
The answer is "no" , and enclosed is copy of the Bureaus letter. You
will not that it is dated Sept 9 th and was a month in transit , 
coming via regular mail--- they couldnt even waste an air-mail stamp
on it ! I dont believe that my request received much consideration.
Whilst my request[ copy of which I enclose together with copy of Capt
Huntoons endoresement] is dated Aug 25 , it was nto mailed from Seattle
until the 28 th. It probably arrived in the Bureau a few days later,
and the fact that it was then answered on Sept 9 th leads me to believe
that it received purely "routine" treatment. It is signed by a Lt.Comdr.
merely signed the letter. I would therefore like to pursue the matter
further untill I'm convinced that some really responsible person has 
decided ont he merits of the case. Each letter from Olive brings me
news of someone being released, and I believe my case more "worthy"
than many.
So, if you are in Washington when this reaches you, I wonder
if you would see hat you can do to help bring my case to the attention
of the "big shot". The enclosed copy of my request gives you my picture
in brief, but I think I had better give you a fuller explanation of
it , so that if you get in an "argument" about the relative merits of
my case as compared to others, you will have some ammunition.
My main argument is that my family needs me more than the Navy.
The money angle is the important one. In my request in paragraphs
[b]xxxx [c] and [d] , I state that in 1941 and 1942 I paid good-sized
income taxes, and since then have paid nothing. This may astonish you
and you may wonder what happened to the money I got from selling out
my share in Zander Co. What happened was this :
Several years ago , a firm in Cincinnati went broke in a big
way. We had such big contracts with them that it resulted in busting
our firm in Santos and practically busting the one in New Orleans.
I borrowed to the hilt against the house, life insurance policies
etc. We struggled along for a few years without any improvement until
[End Page 1]
about four years ago we bought out Bartlett and I got controlling
interest in the firm. I instituted reforms and then, partly from that
and partly from just plain luck , we made good money--[dollar sign]91,000 my last
year if I recall correctly. Then the war xxx came and when I got on
that carrier, I figured my chances were about 50-50 and I had best
put my affairs in order and I sold out to Leo. After paying big income
taxes, and paying off all the loans on the house, life-insurance etc,
there was mighty little left. We have had to live mostly on our capitol
since I got in the Navy , so that now we have less than [dollar sign]30,000 left,
and that doesnt bring much interest when invested in bonds--both War
Bonds and others. So I think you can see----- and I hope you can convince
the guy in Bupers you talk to ! --- that a few more years of this will
just about make me a Social Security problem for our Govt.
If I am released now , there is a swell job waiting for me. As I
previously wrote you, Leo doesn't want to hook up with me again due to
the small coffee quota allowed him by the OPA, and I cant enter business
for myself due to OPA rulings , but I have a proposition form an old
established firm. They are one of the biggest and best in the world,
with offices in New York, San Fancisco, Chicago and all over Central
and South America. They have no office in New Orleans and want me to
open and run one there. They not only handle coffee but many other
items for both import and export. The Name is Otis McAllister Co.,
I give you this in confidence , only to be used if necessary. On no
account mention this otherwise please as for many reasons we wish it
kept secret untill the time arrives when I can get going. Naturally,
this proposition wont be kept open indefinitely. Since our Govt is
very partial as a "Good Neighbor" to our Central and South American
friends , here is the chance to release me to further foster that
spirit. I would not be merely xxxx supplanting someone already in New 
Orleans , as this firm is not represented there at present, so I would
be building new contacts with Latin America.
A very important point to bring out is that I am in an " in
training" status on this ship. This is bxxx brought out in Capt Huntoons
endorsement, copy of which is enclosed. Once I am made officially the 
Exec of the Castor , I fear it will be just that much more difficult
to get released. So far the Capt has agreed to my request to leave me 
in an "intraining" status , but I fear that soon this will end. That is
why I would like to bring this to a head quickly while I'm still in
this status.
Well---I guess that just about covers my "arguments".
Possibly you are wondering why I dont wait untill my own return
to the US to handle this myself. Unfortunately, the date of our return
is very indefinite. Latest rumours are that we will re-load from one 
of the bases out in this area , so as to save time in that long trip
[End Page 2]
back to the US. Most certainly, there is no chance of our being back
there for a couple of months anyway. And I sure dont want to let this
thing die in the meantime , so thats why I'm bothering you. Hope you
dont mind too much !
If you arent able to accomplish anything , my next recourse is to 
enlist the aid of one of our Louisiana Senators, Ellender. He is no
buddy of mine , but some of my friends such as Leon Irwin are fairly
close to him. He is on the Naval Affairs Commitee , so if he wants to,
I imagine he could help. It would be my intention to have Olive see
him herself [ if he is in New Orleans ] or xxxxx else contact him
through a friend. But I would only want to do this as a last resort
as I detest getting mixed up with politicians. I am writing Olive by
this same mail, so she has all the dope. Would you mind either writing
her or phoning her [ Uptown 4396 ] , telling her what results that you
were able to obtain , so that she will then know how to proceed.
If I dont have any luck either through you or Ellender, then I
guess I'll just have to wait untill that long expected xxxxxx Alnav
comes out about men over 38 , and then I can re-submit my request.
Have you heard anything more about that Alnav ? I continue to hear
roumours that "it will be out shortly", but this would surely be at
variance with recent statment of Sec Forrestall's that no one would
be released from the Navy.
Have you and Sidney decided yet as to whether or not you want 
to get out ? Most assuredly plenty of men are doing it every day---
probably by special pull , but they sure as hell are getting out ,
so if others are getting out , I'll be dammed if I see why we should
be the goats.
Well , this thing is plenty long-winded , so will say so long
and amny thanks in advance for anything you can do. Please drop me a 
line air-mail and let me know whats what. Oh Yes-- tell Jo-Jo hello
for me !
Lt.Comdr.A.Legendre,USNR.
USS Castor [AKS-1]
c o FPO, San Francisco, Cal.
[End Page 3]
